name: Franklin Barbecue
description: World-famous barbecue restaurant with legendary brisket and hours-long lines that have become an Austin tradition.
longDescription: Franklin Barbecue is the most celebrated barbecue joint in America, and for good reason. Aaron Franklin's obsessive attention to post oak smoke, premium beef, and perfect timing produces brisket that has won every major barbecue award in existence. The line starts forming before dawn, and waiting 3-4 hours is standard. But when you bite into that perfectly rendered, smoke-kissed brisket with its jet-black bark, you understand why people fly across the country for this experience. The pulled pork, sausage, and ribs are exceptional too.
tips: Order online to skip the line

name: Uchi
description: James Beard Award-winning Japanese farmhouse dining with innovative sushi and omakase in a converted bungalow.
longDescription: Uchi redefined Austin's dining scene when chef Tyson Cole opened this Japanese farmhouse restaurant in a charming South Lamar bungalow. The menu blends traditional Japanese techniques with Texas ingredients, producing dishes that are both surprising and deeply satisfying. The maguro sashimi with goat cheese and cracked pepper is legendary. The omakase experience lets the kitchen take you on a culinary journey through their most creative preparations. Uchi consistently ranks among the best restaurants in Texas and the nation.

name: Launderette
description: Modern American restaurant in a converted laundromat serving creative dishes and craft cocktails in East Austin.
longDescription: Launderette occupies a beautifully converted laundromat in East Austin, and the transformation is as inspired as the food. Chef Rene Ortiz creates dishes that draw from global influences while staying rooted in seasonal, local ingredients. The space retains industrial charm with soaring ceilings and an open kitchen. The brunch is legendary, the dinner menu is inventive, and the craft cocktail program is one of Austin's best. The warm, buzzy atmosphere makes every meal feel like an event.

name: Odd Duck
description: Farm-to-table restaurant on South Lamar featuring small plates with locally sourced ingredients and creative preparation.
longDescription: Odd Duck started as a food trailer and grew into one of Austin's most beloved restaurants. The farm-to-table philosophy isn't just marketing here—the kitchen works directly with local farms and ranches to source ingredients, and the menu changes with the seasons. The small plate format encourages sharing and exploration. The roasted bone marrow, pork belly, and seasonal vegetable dishes are consistently outstanding. The open kitchen creates an energetic atmosphere, and the South Lamar location puts you in the heart of Austin's food scene.
tips: Order several small plates to share

name: Loro
description: Unique Asian smokehouse concept from the teams behind Franklin Barbecue and Uchi, blending Texas BBQ with Thai flavors.
longDescription: When the minds behind Franklin Barbecue and Uchi collaborate, you get Loro—a genre-defying Asian smokehouse that shouldn't work but absolutely does. Smoked brisket meets Thai curry. Crispy rice salad sits next to oak-smoked salmon. The result is a menu that reflects Austin's creative spirit perfectly. The casual outdoor seating, craft cocktails, and approachable prices make it an everyday favorite rather than a special occasion destination. The smoked turkey with Thai herbs and the brisket fried rice are both essential orders.
tips: Smoked turkey with herbs is amazing

name: Suerte
description: Elevated Mexican restaurant in East Austin featuring hand-ground corn, mole traditions, and wood-fire cooking.
longDescription: Suerte brings the deep culinary traditions of Mexico to East Austin with a reverence that borders on devotion. The restaurant grinds its own corn for tortillas, prepares moles from scratch using traditional techniques, and cooks over live fire. The result is Mexican cuisine that honors its roots while embracing the creative energy of Austin. The suadero tacos, whole grilled fish, and handmade tortillas are revelatory. The space itself is beautiful—warm woods, open kitchen, and a sophisticated bar program featuring Mexican spirits.

name: Emmer & Rye
description: Innovative Rainey Street restaurant featuring ancient grains, fermented ingredients, and dim sum-style small plates.
longDescription: Emmer & Rye is one of Austin's most inventive restaurants, anchored by chef Kevin Fink's passion for ancient grains, fermentation, and preservation. The menu features a unique dim sum cart service that rolls through the dining room with spontaneous small plates alongside more substantial entrees. The restaurant's focus on heritage grains—emmer and rye wheat among them—produces breads and pastas with extraordinary depth of flavor. Located on Rainey Street, it occupies a space that perfectly balances sophistication with Austin's casual energy.

name: Ramen Tatsu-Ya
description: Austin's beloved ramen destination with rich tonkotsu broth, handmade noodles, and late-night hours.
longDescription: Ramen Tatsu-Ya has achieved cult status in Austin for their deeply flavorful, soul-warming ramen. The tonkotsu broth simmers for over 60 hours, producing a creamy, pork-bone elixir of extraordinary richness. The original North Lamar location maintains a fun, punk-rock attitude with hip-hop playing and late-night hours. The menu features several ramen styles, each customizable with extra toppings and spice levels. Their mazemen (brothless ramen) is equally addictive. Lines are common, but the noodles are worth every minute of waiting.
tips: Go during off-peak to avoid lines

name: Torchy's Tacos
description: Iconic Austin taco chain known for creative combinations, secret menu, and damn good tacos.
longDescription: Torchy's Tacos started as a food trailer on South First Street and became an Austin institution. Their creative taco combinations—like the Trailer Park (fried chicken, green chiles, lettuce, pico) and the Crossroads (smoked beef brisket, grilled onions, jack cheese)—have defined a generation of Austin eating. The secret menu is a rite of passage for Austin residents. While they've expanded across Texas and beyond, the original South Congress and early locations retain their authentic Austin energy. The green chile queso is practically its own food group.

name: Terry Black's Barbecue
description: Fifth-generation barbecue family serving premium smoked meats on Barton Springs Road with shorter waits than Franklin.
longDescription: Terry Black's Barbecue brings the legendary Black family barbecue tradition to Austin's Barton Springs Road. The Blacks have been smoking meat in Texas since 1932, and the craft shows in every bite. The brisket rivals any in Austin—rich, smoky, and perfectly rendered. Unlike some famous Austin BBQ spots, the waits are more manageable, and the spacious patio with live music creates a quintessential Austin dining experience. The beef ribs are massive and magnificent, and the sides (especially the creamed corn) are a cut above.

name: La Barbecue
description: East Austin barbecue trailer turned permanent spot with devoted following for brisket and ribs.
longDescription: La Barbecue emerged from Austin's food trailer scene to become one of the city's most revered barbecue destinations. Founded by LeAnn Mueller, who comes from barbecue royalty (Louie Mueller Barbecue in Taylor), the restaurant produces brisket with a dark, peppery bark and luscious, melting interior. The beef ribs are comically large and deeply flavorful. Located in East Austin, the vibe is casual and community-oriented, with picnic tables, cold beer, and a line that moves faster than you'd expect. The chipotle sausage is a house specialty worth ordering.
address: 2401 E Cesar Chavez St, Austin, TX 78702
tips: Check social media for sell-out times

name: Salty Sow
description: Sophisticated neighborhood gastropub with craft cocktails, seasonal menu, and a beautiful oak-shaded patio.
longDescription: Salty Sow elevates the gastropub concept with a seasonal menu driven by local sourcing and culinary creativity. The restaurant occupies a charming East Austin house with one of the best patios in the city—shaded by massive oak trees and strung with lights. The menu changes regularly but always features exceptional charcuterie, hearty mains, and inventive vegetable preparations. The craft cocktail program is outstanding, and the weekend brunch draws devoted regulars. It's the kind of place where every neighborhood wishes they had.

name: Justine's Brasserie
description: Romantic French brasserie in East Austin with classic dishes, vintage ambiance, and late-night dining.
longDescription: Justine's Brasserie is pure romance—a French brasserie transplanted to East Austin with vintage Parisian decor, candlelit tables, and a lush garden patio. The menu features classic French bistro fare: steak frites, moules mariniere, duck confit, and a perfectly assembled croque madame. The kitchen stays open late, making it a favorite for industry workers and night owls. The cocktails are French-inspired and beautifully crafted. Justine's has cultivated an atmosphere that feels timeless, sexy, and utterly un-Austin—which is exactly why Austin loves it.
tips: Garden patio is magical at night

name: Lenoir
description: Intimate South Austin restaurant offering a prix fixe 'hot weather food' menu on a magical garden patio.
longDescription: Lenoir is one of Austin's most enchanting dining experiences. Tucked away on South First Street, the restaurant features a magical garden patio surrounded by mature trees and soft lighting. Chef Todd Duplechan serves what he calls 'hot weather food'—a prix fixe menu influenced by Southern, French, and Asian cuisines, all designed for the Texas climate. The intimate setting, exceptional wine program, and thoughtful service create evenings that feel transported from another era. The tasting menu changes seasonally and always surprises.

name: Home Slice Pizza
description: South Congress institution serving authentic New York-style pizza with a side of Austin attitude.
longDescription: Home Slice Pizza is an Austin institution, serving up honest New York-style pizza on South Congress Avenue since 2007. The thin crust has the perfect chew, the sauce is tangy and balanced, and the cheese pulls just right. The main restaurant offers full pies and a full bar, while the takeout window next door serves slices until late—a lifeline for the South Congress bar crowd. The pepperoni is classic perfection, the white pizza is creamy and garlicky, and the vibe is pure Austin fun.
tips: Grab a slice from the window

name: Veracruz All Natural
description: Beloved food truck serving fresh, made-from-scratch migas and breakfast tacos that define Austin morning culture.
longDescription: Veracruz All Natural has become synonymous with Austin's breakfast taco obsession. Started by sisters Reyna and Maritza Vazquez, this food truck operation serves tacos made entirely from scratch with fresh, natural ingredients. The migas taco—eggs scrambled with crispy tortilla strips, peppers, tomatoes, and cheese—is widely considered the best in Austin. The handmade flour tortillas are pillowy and perfect. Multiple locations across the city mean you're never far from their life-changing tacos. Fresh juices and smoothies round out the menu.
address: 1704 E Cesar Chavez St, Austin, TX 78702

name: Uchiko
description: Uchi's sister restaurant in North Austin featuring yakimono grilling and innovative Japanese farmhouse cuisine.
longDescription: Uchiko takes the Uchi formula north, occupying a stunning space on North Lamar that emphasizes yakimono—Japanese-style grilling over bincho-tan charcoal. The menu shares Uchi's creative spirit but carves its own identity with dishes that highlight the grill and seasonal Japanese ingredients. The cool tastings and warm tastings format encourages exploration. The space is architecturally striking with its clean lines and warm wood tones. The happy hour at the bar is one of Austin's best-kept secrets for affordable high-end sushi.
tips: Happy hour at bar is a great deal
Try the cool and warm tastings

name: Epoch Coffee
description: Beloved 24/7 Austin coffee house with strong espresso, relaxed atmosphere, and a loyal community of regulars.
longDescription: Epoch Coffee is the beating heart of Austin's independent coffee culture. Open 24 hours, this beloved coffee house serves excellent espresso, drip coffee, and pastries to a rotating cast of students, remote workers, night owls, and creative types. The North Loop location has the lived-in, welcoming feel of a true community gathering place. Free WiFi, ample seating (including a spacious patio), and a judgment-free atmosphere make it easy to lose hours here. It's where Austin works, studies, and hangs out.
address: 221 W N Loop Blvd, Austin, TX 78751
